results.title: Australia's birds : Woodlands
results.creator_credit: Grant Young, Terence Lindsey and GEO Wildlife Documentaries
results.brief_description: Most Australian woodlands are dominated by trees of a particular group - the eucalypts. Familiar to all Australians these distinctive trees have a number of special characteristics that set them apart, and these unique characteristics provide a wealth of challenges and opportunities for the birds that inhabits Australian woodlands, resulting in one of the richest and most diverse bird communities on the continent. This video focuses on the life histories and special feeding behaviours of 23 species of Australian woodland birds. Birds discussed are: Yellow Robin; Laughing Kookaburra; Grey Burtcherbird; Rufous Songlark; Pallid Cuckoo; Rufous Whistler; Rainbow Bee-eater; Sacred Kingfisher; White-winged Chough; Restless Flycatcher; Speckled Warbler; Peaceful Dove; Double-barred Finch; Varied Sittella; White-throated Treecreeper; Shriketit; Fuscous Honeyeater; Spotted Pardalote; Noisy Friarbird; Regent Honeyeater; Scarlet Honeyeater; Painted Honeyeater; Mistletoe Bird.

results.title: Australia's birds : Oceans
results.creator_credit: Grant Young and GEO Wildlife Documentaries
results.brief_description: Oceans make up about four-fifths of the Earths surface, and there are many kinds of birds that spend their lives roaming these vast expanses between continents, seldom finding themselves even within sight of land. Many come ashore only to nest. In size these ocean wanderers range from the albatrosses - some with wingspans nearing three metres, among the largest birds that fly - to the tiny storm-petrel, little bigger than a starling. This video tells the story of a cross-section of some of the more common and representative of these fascinating ocean wanderers. Birds discussed are: Wandering Albatross; Providence Petrel; Black-winged Petrel; Flesh-footed Shearwater; Wedge-tailed Shearwater; Australasian Gannet; Masked Booby; Sooty Tern; Grey Noddy; Brown Noddy; White Tern; Red-tailed Tropicbird.

results.title: Atomic achievement
results.creator_credit: John Reeve, Anthony Gilkison and Rayant Pictures
results.brief_description: An account of Britain’s vast nuclear power program for a new industrial era, and of progress to date. Operational centres visited by the film include Calder Hall, the first full-scale nuclear power station; the great atomic research centre at Harwell; the atomic factories at Springfields, Capenhurst and Windscale; and the “fast breeder-reactor” under construction at Dounreay. Animated diagrams explain the working of a nuclear reactor.

results.title: At the threshold of eternity
results.creator_credit: Mikel Way and Colorado State University Production Company
results.brief_description: Dr. James Enderson talks about the ways being used to save endangered or threatened wildlife. The following recovery plans: Habitat Management, Transplanting, and Captive Breeding, are shown in practice with wildlife in several areas of the United States.

results.title: As time goes by
results.creator_credit: Barry Peak, Chris Kiely and Valhalla
results.brief_description: Science fiction comedy about a bizarre encounter between a knockabout surfer and an alien, set in the Australian outback. The alien enlists the surfer’s aid in finding the power capsule for his spaceship which is disguised as a 1940’s diner. However, there are others with sinister plans in search of the diner and the surfer finds he must change the course of time. Cast includes Bruno Lawrence, Nique Needles, Ray Barrett and Max Gillies.

results.title: As our boyhood is...
results.brief_description: A documentary which studies the facilities for education - both good and bad - available to Afro-American children in the southern states of the USA during the mid-1940’s. An interesting documentary for its time for its sympathetic attitude towards the plight of Afro-American children in getting an education. Photography by Roger Barlow and Jospeh Braun.

results.title: Area theorems
results.brief_description: Using animated shapes and the manipulation of models (translation and rotation) the facts concerning the area of the triangle, parallelogram and trapezium are demonstrated. An episode from the series “Vision in Mathematics”. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary students.

results.title: Area 1: Barbara arrives in Arealand
results.creator_credit: Agency for Instructional Television and South Carolina TV Network
results.brief_description: In a journey “through her window” Barbara ventures into Arealand for the three programs in the MeasureArea cluster. She explores the concept of area and discovers a variety of ways to determine it with trhe help of many unusual fantasyland characters. In this program Barbara learns that area is two-dimensional and that “covering” is a process to determine area. She encounters square metre, square decimetre and square centimetre. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.
